Award.AwardTitle: Magnetically Supported Accretion Disks Around Black Holes: Observational Diagnostics from Numerical Simulations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Greg Salvesen is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship to carry out a program of research and education at the University of California, Santa Barbara. Salvesen will perform advanced numerical simulations to understand how strong magnetic fields influence black hole X-ray Binaries (BH XRBs), which consist of a black hole feeding on a disk of X-ray emitting gas from a companion star. Understanding BH XRBs is key to learning about other types of black holes as well. The center of nearly every galaxy (including our own) hosts a supermassive black hole surrounded by a disk of gas, but supermassive black holes are very difficult to understand because they change very little over our lifetimes. Because BH XRBs are thought to be scaled down versions of supermassive black holes, and exhibit changes on timescales accessible to astronomers, they are ideal laboratories for studying how material accretes around a black hole. Alongside this work, Salvesen will create a website featuring real astronomical data that have been converted into sound samples, and he will develop workshops to convey classroom astronomy concepts through sound to K-12 students with visual impairments or limited English proficiency.

Salvesen will undertake numerical simulations of strongly magnetized accretion disks to calculate two direct observable quantities of BH XRBs: (1) the spectrum of light emitted by an accretion disk subjected to magnetic fields of various strengths and geometries, as well as quasi-periodic oscillations produced by accretion disk variability; and (2) the spectrum of light absorbed by magnetically driven disk winds, and manifested in diagnostic probes (e.g., spectral lines of highly ionized atoms). Salvesen will then compare the simulations with the observed properties of BH-XRBs to determine if the emission and absorption spectra of these objects can be used to understand the influence of strong magnetic fields on black hole accretion disks. Salvesen will also create the Astronomy Sound of the Month (ASOM) website and develop "sonification" workshops to convey basic astronomy concepts to visually impaired or English-language learning K-12 students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit component of the project involved researching astrophysical systems called black hole X-ray binaries. Their anatomy consists of a black hole in a binary orbit with an evolved star. Gas stripped off the outer layers of the star forms a disk around the black hole. In some circumstances, the disk material close to the black hole can become hot enough (10 million degrees) to emit X-ray light observable with telescopes in space. Sometimes, these systems also eject jets of material moving nearly as fast as the speed of light that radio telescopes can observe. So far, astronomers discovered about two dozen of these black hole X-ray binaries, but we expect there are thousands in our Galaxy alone.

The major completed research project focused on a specific black hole X-ray binary called V4641 Sgr. This system has a severe misalignment (> 60 degrees) between the angular momenta of the binary orbit and that of the black hole. The PI showed that the expected channel for producing a misalignment cannot explain the large misalignment observed in V4641 Sgr. This result calls into question our understanding of how these misalignments come about, which affects measurements of black hole spin and predictions for the gravitational wave signal from merging black holes.

Another project related to misalignments that is near completion focuses on a different black hole X-ray binary called GRO J1655-40. The PI measured the orientation of the disk in this system and found it to be in agreement with the orientation of the jet, confirming the theoretical expectation of disk-jet alignment. This result also supports the idea that the orientation of the disk and the jet can be used to indirectly probe the orientation of the black hole spin, which is otherwise observationally inaccessible.

Two other research projects are nearing completion, both having to do with how magnetic fields affect the properties of these disks around black holes. The first project considers all existing black hole spin measurements that rely on modeling the X-ray continuum from the disk. These measurements do not include uncertainties associated with how magnetic fields in the disk alter the observed X-ray continuum. The PI showed that the effects of magnetic fields are the dominant source of uncertainty and revised the existing black hole spin measurements accordingly. Generally, including a reasonable uncertainty associated with disk magnetization causes the measured black hole spin uncertainty to double.

The second project considers how the thickness of these disks affects their ability to accumulate magnetic fields in the regions close to the black hole. Previous work found that thick disks can accumulate strong magnetic fields, while thin disks cannot. In trying to reproduce this result, the PI discovered several mathematical mistakes in this seminal work. Instead, it appears that the thickness of the disk does not strongly influence its ability to drag magnetic fields inward toward the black hole. Encouragingly, this important analytic result is supported by recent computer simulations of magnetized disks around blacks holes.

The main broader impacts component of the project led to the Astronomy Sound of the Month (AstroSoM) website, which featured real astronomy data turned into sound. The primary goal of these "data sonifications" was to make astronomy accessible to the blind/visually impaired community. AstroSoM showcased 13 installments and received considerable attention from major news outlets (e.g., Newsweek, IFL Science, EarthSky, Gizmodo, APOD) and the "Eyes on Success" podcast, which discusses products, services and daily living tips for people with vision loss.

The PI was also involved with several other broader impacts activities. These included teaching a college physics course to 53 undergraduates at the University of California, Santa Barbara; speaking four times at Astronomy on Tap, a public event with chapters nationwide that features engaging and interactive science presentations at a bar; and giving two invited public talks for regional astronomy clubs in California.
